entries.title: Angular
entries.notes: Considering looking into it, but put it third of the three in priority.

entries.title: Browserify
entries.content:
Collects JS modules (and script files) and mushes them all into a single app file. Often compared to requireJS.

I guess it's similar to the way Node.js requires dependencies, but for compiling to the front end.

entries.title: Burbon
entries.content: Another CSS Framework (in Sass). Not clear on this vs compass.
entries.notes: Might be the framework that I finally accept

entries.title: CoffeeScript
entries.content: Haven't gone too deep, but essentially CoffeeScript just "cleans up" JavaScript. It's all still just javaScript, but cuts out some of the extra semicolons, var declarations, etc.
entries.notes: Will need to spend time, but looking forward to second nature

entries.title: compass
entries.content:
CSS framework (in Sass). It has prebuilt stuff like a reset, some layout stuff, and other mixins.

It's also the preprocessor (gulp node) that does the compiling of Sass.

entries.title: Gulp
entries.content:
Where to start, well, it's like Grunt, but cooler. It's essentially a task manager that runs stuffs. (Alternative to CodeKit too)

Currently using a starting kit from viget.com that breaks it up a bit. But here's how it's working:

  1. Once I've got the project setup, I fire up gulp by cd to project folder and typing gulp.
  2. This fires gulpfile.js, which in turn finds the gulp/index.js file, which in turn looks in the tasks folder for the compartmentalized tasks that gulp runs.
entries.notes: Getting the hang of it. Excited to integrate

entries.title: Handlebars
entries.content:
similar to html, but has {{bracket includes}} stuff going on.

Similar to haml or jade (I think). Something to do with Mustache templates.

Ember mentions something about handlebar integration.

I installed the handlebar package to sublime so it looks more like html, may do other stuff.

entries.title: Imagemin
entries.content: haven't looked too deep in to the node module, but once the gulp task is up and running it seems to just work. Ohh yeah, it optimizes images, that's it's job.

entries.title: jQuery
entries.notes: jQuery 4 life, not really, but you know.

entries.title: LiveReload
entries.content:
If you hook up both ends it creates auto-refresh of a browser on save of files.

  • Need the browser plugin (chrome) and the little icon clicked to "listen"
  • Gulp is kicking this off on it's end with gulp-livereload (on port 35729).

This is very similar to what's being done in CodeKit
entries.notes: get it running and just expect

entries.title: Burbon Neat
entries.content: Neat is a grid framework on top of Burbon. This is the cleanest looking grid system I've come across lately. Potential.
entries.notes: might be the grid system I finally accept, but still hesitant

entries.title: NPM
entries.content: Node Packaged Modules. Ships with nodejs, so I've got it. It's a package manager (like Brew) but just for JavaScript stuff (both back end like nodejs stuff and client side like browserify.)

entries.title: PHP
entries.content: You know, that little language called php.

entries.title: Sass
entries.content:
This is almost second nature now. I'm very comfortable with "full" sass (rather than scss or less), but it all falls back to css pretty easily.

Mixins, functions, variables, includes. Getting it done.

entries.title: Underscore
entries.notes: Not sure why, but I'm really not excited about looking into this
